awd_titl_txt: The untapped community: Community colleges as an opportunity to broaden participation in engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
By the year 2022, the demand for engineers is projected to exceed their anticipated graduation from degree programs by 1 million. With the shifting demographics of the country, there is also an imperative need to attract women and people from groups traditionally underrepresented in engineering to address this workforce shortage. Community colleges are well suited to be a resource in these efforts with the potential to increase both the number and diversity of such qualified engineers. Although community colleges have received much attention in recent years, little is known about the experiences of community college engineering students as they complete their coursework at the community college and transfer to the next stage of their life (e.g., accredited engineering program or their career). As this time period critically influences students' chosen pathways to engineering careers, this study seeks to understand the lived and told experiences of community college engineering students, specifically focusing on those from underrepresented groups (URGs). As this is a budding, diverse pool of talent with promise in meeting the workforce needs, this project has the potential to uncover barriers and catalysts that URGs experience as they progress in their education in multiple contexts. 

This project involves diverse community college programs spanning three U.S. Census regions, which could inform both community college programs and four-year institutions across the country. This work also leverages the progress of prior National Science Foundation investments in community colleges while addressing issues of social justice such as inequity and exclusion, which are perpetuated when pathways to Bachelor's degrees are less accessible for particular groups of students - here, community college students. Specifically, the project will address the following research questions: 
RQ1: What are the lived and told stories of community college engineering students from URGs? 
RQ2: How do URG community college students' understandings of their experiences and the relationship of those experiences to the environment influence their plans for future education and careers? 
RQ3: In what ways, if any, do community college engineering students' narratives bring to light issues of oppression, privilege and inequality? 

In this narrative inquiry project, the project will conduct a series of in-depth interviews with participants from underrepresented groups at three community college systems in Virginia, Texas, and Arizona, where the selected institutions each serve large numbers of students from underrepresented groups.  These community colleges were chosen intentionally as they have close proximity to and/or articulation agreements with four-year institutions with engineering programs. Gaining a better understanding of student experiences promises to enable proactive development of strategies to position and prepare students to pursue four-year degrees from the inception of their studies at community colleges. Moreover, findings from this study promise to shed light on why existing efforts to increase transfer rates to four-year institutions have had limited effectiveness, which could inform academia, industry, and government.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
Accomplishments 

 

  1. 1.     Significant Results: 

Key outcomes or other achievements: 

A paper reporting the analysis of the photo elicitation data from the interviews of Spring 2020 is written and published at Qualitative Research Journal. This is one of the top tiered journals in the field of qualitative inquiry. The goal of this study was to explore an immediate step in understanding the lived experiences of under-represented students through metaphor construction and possibly collect more in-depth data through photograph-based interviews. This article introduced photo-elicitation based narrative interviews as a qualitative methodology while interviewing fourteen undergraduate community college students mostly from underrepresented groups (URGs). At the beginning of each interview, the authors probed the participants with 8 photographs chosen by the research team to represent a diverse set of experiences in engineering. The authors conducted a thematic analysis of the interview data. 

Another paper focused on the value of community college is also accepted at the New Directions for Community College. A greater understanding of students’ experiences could elucidate early interventions and strategic opportunities to foster an awareness and desire among community college engineering students to transfer to four-year institutions. 

One American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE. 2022) paper was written based on the data from the grant. It is the goal of this paper was to understand the effect that stigma has on the decision to go to community college but also for those that do choose to venture into community college, what has been their experience. Leading to the research question of this study; how has the stigma associated with community college impacted students' decisions to attend a community college? What do the stories of students that attended community college reveal about braving the stigma?

 

Also, we are working on another paper on the effectiveness of STEM promise program for the underrepresented groups (URGs). 

 

Based on the social justice aspects of this work and preliminary findings, the PI was invited to serve as Co-PI on an INCLUDES proposal that was submitted in July 2020. Additionally, the PI will be working on another INCLUDES Alliance proposal that seeks to establish a network of stakeholders focused on the pathways from the community college to the 4-year institution.

What opportunities for training and professional development has the project provided? 

During this year of the project, a postdoctoral researcher engaged with more in-depth data analysis. The postdoc researcher played a significant role in developing a codebook, that is combination of inductive and deductive codebook. Developing the codebook and analyzing the data took place in different phases. The postdoc researcher went through every transcript and identified the overarching themes and at the same time based on literature review and research questions the postdoc researcher developed the deductive codes. The team met a few times to ensure inter-rater reliability. The postdoc researcher and a PhD student in engineering education developed a robust plan for data dissemination. 

Through this exposure, the postdoc researcher has been able to develop new related research questions and is leading a grant focused on curriculum adaptation and culturally responsive pedagogy of faculty members at two year and four-year institutions. 

Also, two REU students are working on the project. One of the students is working to find an easier way of presenting data through data visualization and another REU student is getting training on literature review related to the value of community college project. She also got hands -on training on data analyses and contributing in writing the article. 

How have the results been disseminated to communities of interest? 

Journals or Juried Conference Papers
View all journal publications currently available in the NSF Public Access Repository for this award. 

The results in the NSF Public Access Repository will include a comprehensive listing of all journal publications recorded to date that are associated with this award. 

Journal Publications

  • Maitra, D. & Coley, B. (2022). "Marginalized engineering students' narrative construction through photo elicitation", Qualitative Research Journal, https://doi.org/10.1108/QRJ-10-2021-0110 

 

  • Maitra, D., Coley, B., and Greene, C. (2022). Community Values: Exploring What Underrepresented Engineering Students Value in their Community College Experience. New Directions for Community Colleges (under review)

 

Conference Publications

Reyes, D., & Coley, B. C. (2022). The Mist Shrouding Community College. ASEE Annual Conference and Exposition, Conference Proceedings, Minneapolis, MN.

Boklage, A and Kellam, N and Cirell, A & Coley, B. (2018). ASEE Conference Proceedings. An exploration of the diverse stories of engineering students at community colleges: Findings from year one. 1-11. Status = Deposited in NSF-PAR Federal Government's License = Acknowledged. (Completed by Kellam, null on 06/20/2018 ) Full text Citation details 

Coley, B. Thomas, K. , Greene, M., Kellam, N., & Boklage, A. (2018).  Community Values: Understanding what Underrepresented Engineering Undergraduates Value in Attending Community College. Proceedings of the American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) Intl. Mtg., Montréal, Québec, Canada, abstract accepted. Status = ACCEPTED

 

 


Last Modified: 11/07/2022
Modified by: Brooke C Coley
